content: Since February, we had a $1 billion revenue target with a 15% adjusted EBITDA margin for the fourth quarter and our guidance today is comfortably ahead of these targets. Nurse and Allied segment revenue was $828 million in the third quarter, 32% higher year-over-year and declining 25% sequentially. For the fourth quarter, we expect revenue in Nurse and Allied Solutions to be down 7% sequentially and approximately 29% year-over-year due primarily to the reduction in bill rates weâve discussed. In our Physician and Leadership Solutions segment, third quarter revenue was $175 million, showing 16% growth over the prior year, slightly better than our guidance. In the third quarter, Technology and Workforce Solutions segment revenue of $135 million grew 35% year-over-year, better than our guidance of 30%. For the fourth quarter, we expect revenue in Technology and Workforce Solutions to grow approximately 10% year-over-year with similar increases in all major business lines. Adjusted SG&A, excluding certain nonrecurring expenses and stock-based compensation expense, was $204 million this quarter or 17.9% of revenue compared with $168 million or 19.2% of revenue in the year ago quarter. In the third quarter, Nurse and Allied revenue was $828 million, 32% higher than prior year and down 25% from prior quarter. Physician and Leadership Solutions revenue in the third quarter was $175 million, 16% higher year-over-year and flat sequentially. Technology and Workforce Solutions revenue was $135 million in the third quarter, growing 35% year-over-year and down 10% from the prior quarter. In February, based on our anticipated fourth quarter exit rate, we laid out a framework for 2023 expectations, including $4 billion of annualized revenue and a 15% adjusted EBITDA margin. Based on the midpoint of our current guidance for the fourth quarter of 2022, the same approach implies $4.26 billion of revenue and an adjusted EBITDA margin of approximately 15.3%. And then I would also just point out that when you think about the year-over-year revenue decline in Nurse and Allied, we only have $8 million of labor disruption revenue in the fourth quarter guide, and thatâs comparing against $85 million last year. Mark, on your â23 question, I would just say, with the flattening in the bill rates that weâve seen post September and where demand sits not just within Nurse and Allied but across PLS and the revenue growth that we are seeing in Technology and Workforce Solutions, I think thatâs what gave us the confidence to talk about annualizing the fourth quarter number. But where weâre sitting right now for what we see from the September numbers to where weâre at right now, we think the worst is behind us from these 9% or 11% or 14% sequential decline that weâve seen, and we think the fourth quarter, for all intents and purposes, outside of seasonal fluctuations next year, that weâve reached the bottom.
